This was my first time having sea urchin, but the creaminess and freshness of all the seafood was memorable. I don‚Äôt think the urchin made the dish - the scallops and salsa would have been great on their own, but the urchin added some nice buttery texture that added to it. I can‚Äôt wait to return!

reviews.raw_text:
I have been coming here a couple years in the making and it‚Äôs only gotten more popular! I recently got the fish taco and shrimp taco to keep things simple and it didn‚Äôt break the bank! You can still spend under $15 here and enjoy with the flavor they provide! It‚Äôs one of the freshest flavors you will try and the four salsas they have are quite selective with the choices from smoked chiles and habanero chiles. The seafood level of freshness is freshly caught and always sure to be served to the best quality levels possible. One thing that I love is the thickness of the tortillas. They are freshly made and keep their texture together with each bite you take. I would put Holbox above any typical seafood restaurant. It is going to blow your mind and if you are open to eating raw or cooked in lime shellfish, you are in for a treat beyond your imagination. Highly recommend it to all, go ahead and give it a try and take this as a sign to order more than one item on the menu.

reviews.raw_text:
Holbox completely lived up to and honestly exceeded its Michelin-star reputation. We ordered the scallop ceviche, kampachi, lobster, and the fresh uni‚Ä¶ and every dish was an absolute standout.

The scallop ceviche was bright and silky, bursting with clean citrus flavors. The kampachi had that perfect buttery texture, so fresh it practically melted. The lobster was rich, sweet, and cooked to perfection. But the uni wow. Creamy, briny, and unbelievably fresh‚Ä¶ now I fully understand why Holbox earned its Michelin star.

Every plate was thoughtful, balanced, and executed with precision. This is seafood at its highest level innovative, respectful of the ingredients, and genuinely unforgettable.

Holbox remains one of LA‚Äôs true culinary gems. If you love world-class seafood, this place is non-negotiable.

reviews.raw_text:
One of several restaurants in a food hall.  You order at the counter (or with an auxiliary person near the counter if it‚Äôs busy), seat yourself, and they bring your food to you - a surprisingly smooth and speedy process. There‚Äôs a QR code menu just inside the door, but you must ask for the paper menu to see allergen info.  Tried 2 tostadas (kanpachi ceviche w uni, smoked kanpachi) and 3 tacos (smoked kanpachi, octopus, scallop), and side of cilantro rice ($2).  Tacos were superior, particularly the smoked kanpachi and the octopus!  Tostadas were good but sum not greater than parts.

I come back here for the Baja Fish Taco. I've tried a few other things on the menu, that were on point as well, I mean even the salsa that comes with the chips is bangin'. But no lie, I've never had a better fish taco than the one they serve here. Holbo is killing it over at Mercado La Paloma. The line goes out, and around back of the building. But its well worth the wait. I'd like to give a shout out to to all the staff. You'd think they'd be burnt out from the intensity of the customers piling in--but they're there with their A-game, its obvious they're passionate about what they represent. I intend on experiencing their tasting menu one day. I'd highly recommend checking them out!!

reviews.raw_text:
I came here for the seafood and left questioning my emotional readiness for a live cooking demonstration. The tostada? Was amazing. The aqua chile? Just ok, but I‚Äôve had better elsewhere. I also tried the uni scallop ‚Äî buttery, oceanic, and definitely worth a try.

The real plot twist was watching a lobster flailing after being cut in half alive. Not exactly the tableside performance I was hoping for. ü¶ûüò≥

All in all, the food‚Äôs fresh and delicious, but the hype is in the Michelin rating. There‚Äôs great seafood in L.A., and Holbox is up there ‚Äî just maybe‚Ä¶ bring emotional support if you‚Äôre squeamish.

I‚Äôll go again to check it out one more time. The line is real.

reviews.raw_text:
Definitely appreciate a top rated restaurant that isn‚Äôt pricing out half the population. So 5 stars for that.

Service doesn‚Äôt really count‚Äîthere aren‚Äôt waiters here. We waited in line, ordered, and sat and waited for our food for about an hour total on a Sunday at 530. Not crazy, considering its high ratings.

That being said, the smoked taco was incredible(!), but everything else was good, not great. I would do the taco again in a heartbeat, but would skip entering else.

Loved the setting, there‚Äôs several other restaurants that looked delicious as well in the food hall.

I should also say I‚Äôm not a ceviche person (but I love sushi), so maybe it‚Äôs  the wrong type of restaurant for me.

reviews.raw_text:
Hidden inside Mercado La Paloma, Holbox is a Michelin-starred seafood counter that completely lives up to the hype.
We tried the uni & scallop tostada ‚Äî freshly opened sea urchin topped with scallop and green salsa, unbelievably sweet and creamy.
The Filete al Carbon (grilled sea bass with cilantro rice) was perfectly cooked ‚Äî crispy skin, tender meat, and full of flavor.
Both octopus and fried fish tacos were light, crunchy, and fresh, especially with their house-made hot sauces.
The Kanpachi ceviche was bright and balanced, a perfect mix of acid and spice.

Everything tasted so clean and ocean-fresh.
It‚Äôs a casual spot, not fancy at all, but the quality easily rivals high-end restaurants.

reviews.raw_text:
This is a fantastic food and at a great price point for an one michelin star restaurant.  The atmosphere is nothing to write home about as it is in a food hall and you find your own table.  But you do not come here for the atmosphere...  It is the food.  The seafood is super fresh - you really can taste the freshness.  We ordered multiple tacos - baja fish, shrimp, octopus, grilled fish, grilled branzino, ceviche...  Each dish was great.  The price - ridiculously inexpensive...  For all the food we ordered, the total bill was about $125 with tips...  A long wait, however.  We arrived @ around 2:00 PM on Saturday and waited for almost one hour!  Worth it, however

reviews.raw_text:
Chef Gilberto Cetina draws deeply from his Yucat√°n roots to create a seafood-marisquer√≠a experience that feels both authentic and elevated. The menu features ceviches, tostadas, aguachiles and tacos, all built around fresh, well-sourced local seafood with bold citrus, chile and brine flavors.

Located inside Mercado La Paloma in South-Central L.A., a food-hall environment, Holbox is unpretentious and energetic but still delivers on incredible high-end cooking.

The restaurant has earned major recognition: a Michelin star (2024) and a ranking in the top echelon of LA and North America‚Äôs best restaurants.

Reservations are an absolute must and are next to impossible to get given the limited number of counter seats. A fair amount of persistence will be required to dine here.

For those in LA craving top-tier seafood, a pilgrimage to Holbox is an absolute must. Note that service is brisk and all dishes are served at the same time. Portions are also substantial so be sure to come hungry!

reviews.raw_text:
Definitely worth doing a little drive to get to this elevated food court and trying Holbox. This is some of the city‚Äôs best fresh Mexican cuisine, with a focus on seafood.

Do yourself a favor and order a bunch of stuff, it‚Äôs worth it. We got: Branzino, Scallop Aguachile, fresh Santa Barbara Uni, Kanpachi & Uni Tostada, Kanpachi Taco, and Baja Fish Taco.

Overall, whatever you do, get the Scallop Aquachile and something with Sea Urchin. By far, probably the best Sea Urchin I‚Äôve had in my life. The Smoked Kampachi Taco was quite good too, it had a peanut chili oil (Salsa Macha) which I‚Äôve never seen before until here. Really cool.

The Branzino was fresh and cooked perfectly, with insanely good blue corn tortillas to go alongside. The Baja Fish taco was pretty standard.

All in all, I try to come here every time I come to LA now. You get FRESH FRESH FISH here and it shows. Recently, there‚Äôs been lines out the door. Worth the wait, I think, but maybe come at a weird time and you won‚Äôt have to worry.

All of this order was like $100.

My brother took me this Michelin-starred seafood place. Though it‚Äôs in a food hall, it‚Äôs not food hall prices. The quality of the dishes were still outstanding and worthy of the cost.

The highlight for me was the sopa de mariscos. The flavors reminded me of how we used to have it as a youth, if not the texture. The seafood was abundant and fresh. Other highlights include the delicious tostadas and the fresh uni and scallop. Try all the dishes with their home made hot sauces.

Though the wait was about 25 minutes to be sat at prime dinner time, it‚Äôs still definitely worth it. We‚Äôll be back.

reviews.raw_text:
Amazing very high quality seafood taco options at an affordable price. The Baja fish tacos were so crispy and so tasty, my wife loved it, we had to order a second round! The Baja shrimp tacos were also great and a good size compared to any shrimp tacos I ever had. The octopus tacos were cooked just right and were large enough to have a good chew and bite and I really liked the sauce that came with it. The scallops taco was cooked to perfection like I‚Äôve never tasted scallops this well cooked before! Finally, it was my first time to try sea urchins, and they were absolutely delicious! I loved how it was presented and the I really enjoyed the ceviche that came with it. It was so fresh and creamy it melted in my mouth. Great staff and food service. I highly recommend as a first time Michelin star restaurant on a budget.

The Baja shrimp tacos were also great and a good size compared to any shrimp tacos I ever had. The octopus tacos were cooked just right and were large enough to have a good chew and bite and I really liked the sauce that came with it. The scallops taco was cooked to perfection like I‚Äôve never tasted scallops this well cooked before! Finally, it was my first time to try sea urchins, and they were absolutely delicious! I loved how it was presented and the I really enjoyed the ceviche that came with it. It was so fresh and creamy it melted in my mouth. Great staff and food service. I highly recommend as a first time Michelin star restaurant on a budget.

reviews.raw_text:
Came here with a friend for lunch on Friday and this place totally deserves its Michelin star. We got there about 15 minutes before opening, so parking was easy and we were part of the first group in line.

Holbox serves Yucat√°n-style seafood tacos, and every single one we tried was incredible. We ordered the scallop taco, octopus taco, smoked kanpachi taco, Baja fish taco, and the aguachile with spot prawn and scallops. The scallop was buttery and sweet, the octopus was super tender with that perfect char, and the smoked kanpachi had this deep, smoky flavor that was just insane. The aguachile was bright, spicy, and refreshing‚Äîperfect for a warm day.

The service was exceptional. You order at the counter, and they somehow manage to bring everything out quickly and perfectly timed, even with so many tables scattered around the market. It‚Äôs impressive how smoothly everything runs.

We finished with the churros and chocolate sauce, which were the perfect ending‚Äîcrispy, light, and the chocolate was rich but not overly sweet.

The small lot is paid (about $4 an hour), but there‚Äôs some free street parking if you get lucky. Definitely worth coming a little early for a spot.

Can‚Äôt wait to come back and try more of the menu, especially anything with uni. This place is a gem.

Atmosphere: 4

Parking space: Difficult to find parking

We visited Holbox and the experience was very good overall. We ordered octopus, octopus tacos, shrimp tacos, and lemonade with soda.

The octopus was very well prepared, tender, and flavorful. The octopus and shrimp tacos were an excellent choice: a good portion, fresh ingredients, and well presented.

The lemonade with soda was refreshing, although a little sweet for my taste.

The service was friendly and fast, and the atmosphere is relaxed, ideal for enjoying seafood with friends or family.

Overall, a recommended experience if you like seafood with a twist.

I wish I could lobotomize myself so I can try this once again. I dead-ass had a ratatouille moment, smiled to myself, and got transported for like two seconds to my childhood. The tostada that sent me was: Tostada de Jurel  Local wild caught yellowtail, almond salsa macha, avocado puree... The other food we devoured and savoured was... Ceviche Mixto: wild Mexican shrimp, Yucatan octopus & local halibut ceviche, and Scallop Aguachile: baja bay scallops, lime-serrano-cilantro marinade, avocado... and the Sopa de Mariscos Seafood stew, local fish, mussels, shrimp, local rockfish, house made fish sausage & grilled bread ... and I could care less about the Baja Fish Taco  Crispy battered local rockfish, crema, mayo, salsa roja, pico de gallo.

reviews.raw_text: Excellent staff!
reviews.plain_text: Excellent staff!

reviews.raw_text:
After a serious ceremony at Malibu Beach, I decided to have something special. Then the nightmare started. It was only about 28 miles, but I spent almost two hours to arrive at Holbox. I don't know why the traffic was so horrible that day, or maybe it was just as normal as every day.

For friends who know me, I don't go to fine dining frequently. I had too much fine dining back in Shanghai. I'd rather find interesting dining spots--inside food courts, at food trucks, etc. Holbox is a Michelin one-star restaurant, but not pricey. Even though it's in a food court and not a traditional restaurant, it's interesting. The food booth doesn't have its own tables in the food court; they're shared with others.

It's a Mexican food booth. The boss lady--puebla in Spanish--was tough, but not rude. As with most Michelin spots, there was a queue, but it wasn't too long. I grabbed a table stand and found us a place to sit.

Not long after, the food was served. The free tortilla chips had no shining points--just as normal as in every Mexican restaurant. Crispy, flat dipping, better than nothing. Good for snacking after a long drive.

The food was served one by one, or you could say delivered one by one:

Erizo 5/5
The word erizo in Spanish means hedgehog, but it can also mean sea urchin. They actually look quite similar. Basically, it's sea urchin. Not everyone likes it--some love it, some hate it. I'm a big fan, uni in Japanese. There were two sea urchins, each with about four or five roes. Underneath were fish and scallop ceviches, but different from normal ceviche--it was lighter, without vinegar or lemon taste, more pure raw seafood. I liked it. Not cheap at $27 for an appetizer.

Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta (Octopus Taco) 5/5
Basically, it's an octopus taco, mixed with squid ink or cuttlefish in--I couldn't tell. The ink mostly gave it color, with just a faint hint of the sea for flavor. Each taco had a giant octopus tentacle--three tacos on a plate, one tentacle for each. The texture was excellen--soft, tender, not juicy but still moist, not fishy at all. I bet the octopus was stewed for a long time, which made it so tasty. Very good. $7 for three, which I wouldn't call expensive--actually well priced.

Pescado a las Brasas 5/5
Fish, who doesn't like fish? A few-bone fish, no tiny bones. The seabass had only one big bone but no tiny bones between the muscles. It was grilled seabass, not heavily marinated but well seasoned. The freshness was its biggest strength.

Cilantro Rice and Black Beans 5/5
The rice was served with the grilled seabass, dipped in stewed black beans. I had never tried that before, but it was tasty. Not too much cilantro aroma, but still good. The rice itself was perfectly cooked--grains separated, not sticky. Paired with the black beans, it was a great match.

I recommend this food booth in the food court, not only because of its Michelin crown, but also for the way they used squid/cuttlefish ink, how they treated cilantro, lemon, and avocado. They truly put heart into making good food.

Meal type: Dinner
Price per person: $30‚Äì50
Food: 5
Service: 2
Atmosphere: 5
Noise level: Moderate noise
Seating type: Indoor dining area, Booth seating, Counter seating

Underneath were fish and scallop ceviches, but different from normal ceviche--it was lighter, without vinegar or lemon taste, more pure raw seafood. I liked it. Not cheap at $27 for an appetizer.

Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta (Octopus Taco) 5/5
Basically, it's an octopus taco, mixed with squid ink or cuttlefish in--I couldn't tell. The ink mostly gave it color, with just a faint hint of the sea for flavor. Each taco had a giant octopus tentacle--three tacos on a plate, one tentacle for each. The texture was excellen--soft, tender, not juicy but still moist, not fishy at all. I bet the octopus was stewed for a long time, which made it so tasty. Very good. $7 for three, which I wouldn't call expensive--actually well priced.

Pescado a las Brasas 5/5
Fish, who doesn't like fish? A few-bone fish, no tiny bones. The seabass had only one big bone but no tiny bones between the muscles. It was grilled seabass, not heavily marinated but well seasoned. The freshness was its biggest strength.

Cilantro Rice and Black Beans 5/5
The rice was served with the grilled seabass, dipped in stewed black beans. I had never tried that before, but it was tasty. Not too much cilantro aroma, but still good. The rice itself was perfectly cooked--grains separated, not sticky. Paired with the black beans, it was a great match.

I recommend this food booth in the food court, not only because of its Michelin crown, but also for the way they used squid/cuttlefish ink, how they treated cilantro, lemon, and avocado. They truly put heart into making good food.

Holbox is a hidden gem that seafood lovers shouldn‚Äôt miss!
Every dish we tried was beautifully presented and bursting with fresh, vibrant flavors:
‚Ä¢	The scallop taco on a blue corn tortilla was perfectly seared and paired with a bright, tangy sauce‚Äîsimple yet unforgettable.
‚Ä¢	The fresh sea urchin served right in the shell was creamy and sweet, a true taste of the ocean.
‚Ä¢	The grilled octopus with green rice and black beans had a wonderful char and tender bite.
‚Ä¢	And the octopus ceviche was light, citrusy, and refreshing with a touch of avocado for creaminess.

Service was warm and welcoming, and the colorful tiled tables made the whole experience feel festive and authentic.

If you‚Äôre looking for outstanding seafood with a creative Mexican twist, Holbox is absolutely worth the trip. Highly recommended

reviews.raw_text:
Lived up to the hype, Holbox is special!!

Was in LA for two days and took an hour uber to check this place out. Unexpected location in a food court of an easy to miss building, but the food is AMAZING. Staff was kind, attentive, and helpful. Prices are very reasonable.

Most unique dish was the uni served in the sea urchin with scallop ceviche. Just a cool experience and tasted amazing. Uni was just a mildly sweet, creamy, and ocean brine/salt flavor.

I‚Äôd 100% get the fish tacos and the blue fin tuna ceviche with tostadas again every time. Both of those were the best of I‚Äôve ever had and were just insanely fresh and flavorful.

The octopus was GREAT, but just not something I‚Äôd get every time.

This place is simply amazing! The best ceviche I have ever had.

reviews.plain_text: This place is simply amazing! The best ceviche I have ever had.

reviews.raw_text:
Seeing as this was my first time dining here - I grabbed a little bit of everything. Here is my review by item:

Halibut tostada - 10/10 - Spectacular, by far the best halibut ceviche I have had to date. The fish is premium quality and melt-in your mouth and the exact right amount of citrus to spice.

Atun Tostada (Tuna Ceviche) - 7/10 - Good. The fish is very fresh but the flavor profile of the ceviche mix can use some work. Also, I am a seafood lover and the white-ish sauce paired with the tuna looked unappealing at first presentation, even to me.

Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta (Braised Octopus taco)  - 0/10 - Disgusting!!!! So gross the lingering flavor was making me nauseous on the ride home. (Note: Ive eaten octopus many times - I tried this based on many good experiences). You get a big tortilla with just a piece of crisped (bland) octopus that tasted old and had an extremely gamey flavor. I hated this. Regret ordering it.

Scallop Taco - 1/10 - A throwaway dish undeserving of the good money paid for it. Turns out Scallops don‚Äôt belong in tacos. Being such a novelty I just had to try it. Huge mistake. Again, the tortilla to filling ratio was way off. All I could taste was bread. The scallops were extremely bland, had a boiled texture - no sear, no char. With only 2 scallops in a thick tortilla, it was like they weren‚Äôt even there. Such a waste of perfectly good scallops. Hated this.

All 3 stars are for the ceviches (tostadas). The cooked seafood is so awful I am insulted I was charged money for them as I feel I should be paid for the trouble of eating them.

Atmosphere: 4

reviews.raw_text:
Ordered for two people:
- Tostada de mero $11
- Scallop aguachile $16
- Ceviche mixto $20
- Smoked kanpachi taco $7
- Scallop taco $5
- Filete al carbon $16
- Onsite parking: < $3 for one hour
- Total: about $90, or ~$45/person with leftovers

The aguachile and ceviche had the same mild flavor but with different proteins, so it would have been sufficient to have ordered one or the other. The octopus in the ceviche was tender unlike other places that are rubbery and hard to chew, nor was it fishy, so you know it's fresh.

The kanpachi taco was a bit too salty.

The green rice that came with the filete al carbon was surprisingly tasty and actually one of our favorite parts.

The salsas are extremely spicy (rare and appreciated) and best to use as a few droplets rather than lather over the tacos.

As for the experience, we had read that the lines would be long and went with flexible expectations and acknowledged that it was a possibility we may arrive and not have a chance to try it. Arrived around 11:30 AM on a Thursday and the line was out the door. The parking lot and street parking were full and people there said it would be about an hour wait so we got a printed menu to go (since it changes every day). We did not feel comfortable leaving our cars so far away from view so we stayed inside it, reviewed the menu, called to order, and waited 45 minutes for the food. When we returned to pick up the food, we managed to get a parking spot as a person left. We chose parking for one hour for around $2.75 since 2 hours was around $8. Since it's a food court, we were able to eat our "to-go" food anywhere except at the Holbox bar.

This was our first Michelin star experience and probably one of the most affordable options out there, so we'll definitely recommend it for budget-conscious people looking for exceptionally fresh and quality ingredients. However, the flavor itself was pretty mild and parking is extremely limited, so be prepared to pay with your time (maybe get in line first at 10:30 AM before it opens).

Atmosphere: 5

Wait time: 1+ hour
Parking space: Difficult to find parking

Has been awhile since we been back here.  Had an opportunity to introduce my niece visiting from Minnesota to real seafood and real Yucat√°n food.  Worth the drive here from the Inland Empire area.  This is located in a food halls where other food stalls.  We went straight to the line, 15-30 min wait.  Ordered at the counter and pick a table and they will bring your food out.
We ordered scallops Aguachiles, pulpo a la brasa and Kanpachi collar.  All the dishes are so fresh especially the Scallops are melted in your mom.  They have a condiments station where all the hot sauce is homemade.  Some are spicer than others but all are really good.  Vibrant dining hall and the noise level is pretty decent.  Plenty of off street and designated parking lot.  Have to go again to try other food stalls in this building.

Such a cute place to dine out.  Food court spot/market with other food counter  options.  The outdoor dining area is so cute.  Easy to find a spot to sit.  They have a small parking lot and also have off street parking as well.   All the ceviche dishes are divine.  The fish taco was crispy and excellent with the variety of hot sauces to bump it up a notch.

I had the kanpachi tacos, octopus chaco, seafood ceviche, uni tostada, and lemonade. Each was incredibly fresh and delicious. üòç
There's always a long line, so choose a time that's a bit awkward.

reviews.raw_text:
Holbox is an absolute gem! This Michelin-star spot serves some of the freshest seafood I‚Äôve had in LA, and the prices are surprisingly democratic for this caliber of food. We tried the smoked kanpachi taco (a must-have‚Äîit‚Äôs phenomenal), the scallop taco, a lobster dish, sea urchin over scallops, and ahi tuna ceviche. Every single bite was bursting with freshness and flavor.

Their sparkling lemonade was perfectly balanced‚Äînot too sweet‚Äîand paired beautifully with the food. I also loved their variety of salsas, each one distinct and thoughtfully crafted to complement the dishes.

We went on a Saturday around noon and had to wait about 40 minutes, but it was well worth it. Holbox is tucked inside a local mercado, so it doesn‚Äôt feel like a stand-alone restaurant, but that only adds to its charm.

I‚Äôll definitely be back to explore more of the menu‚Äîand without question for more of those unforgettable smoked kanpachi tacos!

reviews.raw_text:
Holbox is a seafood paradise where every dish feels alive with flavor and precision. The oysters are pristine and briny, paired simply with salsas and lime that heighten their natural freshness. The ceviche is bright and elegant, perfectly balanced between citrus and herbs. The seafood soup is a standout, a rich and soulful broth layered with shrimp, mussels, and fish, crowned with vibrant cabbage for crunch and contrast. The pulpo/octopus taco is unforgettable, smoky and tender against the earthy blue corn tortilla, lifted by lime and tomato. Holbox captures the essence of coastal cooking at its highest level, refined, soulful and unforgettable. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

I fell in love with Holbox on a recent trip to LA. Every dish was a work of art bursting with bold colors and flavors that were as striking on the palate as they were on the plate. The ceviche was a crisp, refreshing reward after a long, hot day. The prawns and scallops in a spicy green aguachile delivered a perfect balance of heat and brightness, while the Maine lobster was pure indulgence, a true showstopper. Even the soft-shell crab impressed with its delicate crunch and depth of flavor.

Holbox isn‚Äôt just a meal‚Äîit‚Äôs a celebration of freshness, creativity, and culinary craftsmanship. I can‚Äôt wait to return to this immaculate gem.

reviews.raw_text:
Finally got to experience Holbox, and it lived up to the hype. Located inside a food hall, the line can stretch out the door depending on when you arrive, but the counter service setup moves efficiently.

We ordered: Tostada de Kanpachi & Uni, Sea Urchin, Scallop Aguachile, Smoked Kanpachi Taco, Taco de Pulpo, Blood Clams, and Langosta al Carb√≥n.

Everything was fresh and delicious. The standouts were the tostada, uni, smoked Kanpachi taco, and the grilled lobster. The Uni was fresh and buttery, served in its shell with scallop and an aioli-like sauce of somekind, mouthwatering. Lobster was grilled evenly, pre broken, served with melted butter, avocado tomatoes, and what can go wrong with a live lobster? Nothing, and they weighed the lobster in front of us, let us snap photos despite being so busy which was sweet of them. The smoked kanpachi taco was great with tender fish and a crunchy blue corn shell. The only dishes we wouldn‚Äôt order again were the blood clams, and octopus taco. The taco was chewy and the clams just didn't stand out among the rest.

The food came out as it was ready, so pacing wasn‚Äôt ideal, but understandable for this kind of spot.

All in all, Holbox is absolutely worth a visit. Just try not to get distracted by the empty stalls around it lol

reviews.raw_text:
Came in with high hopes due to the Michelin rating and was not disappointed. My wife and I decided to do a huge sampling of whatever caught our eye on the menu.

The Spot Prawn and Scallop Aguachile was super fresh (prawns grabbed right out of the tank) and refreshing. The lime cilantro chile sauce was crisp and tasty with a hint of heat. Great summer dish.

Being a huge ceviche fan we had the Ceviche de Atun. The bluefin tuna was superb. Another well balanced crisp dish that you couldn‚Äôt stop eating.

The star of our meal though was the Tostada de Kanpachi & Uni. An absolute masterpiece. Beautifully layered textures and tastes. The uni was like icing on the cake to some amazing flavors. Even the tostada had amazing flavor. Would come back just for this dish!

The Pulpo a las Brasas was a pick of mine as I am a sucker for octopus. Super tender with a light char and smokiness. Not sure what the sauce was underneath but it was velvety smokey deliciousness. Even the side of cilantro rice and beans were top notch.

Tacos: We had the Baja Fish Taco and the Smoked Kanpachi Taco. Best fish taco I have ever had in my life. Fish was crisp and not greasy. Perfect amount of crema and salsa. The Kanpachi taco was delicious as well but the Baja taco was just a masterpiece of a taco staple. One thing that got my attention in both was the blue corn tortillas. This is what a tortilla is supposed to be. Never had such delicious tortillas in my life. Crazy how the smallest part of the dish can hold up everything and compete in flavor with the exotic ingredients.

Also enjoyed: we had the sparkling lemonade (tasted more like orange to me). Whatever was in it was amazing and refreshing. Not too sweet.

Pricing: who cares. I thought for the level of execution and the quality of ingredients the dishes would be a value at even a higher price point. Great value in my eyes.

Unpretentious culinary adventure in a food hall. Keep doing what you are doing! You have an amazing team kicking out some amazing food!

reviews.raw_text: A little disappointing. The line moved quickly on a Sunday 7pm evening with about a 30min wait. The plating of the dishes was phenomenal especially for a food court.  However the taste and textures disappeared.  The octopus was too soft and mushy, the grilled shrimp was overwhelmed by tomato sauce, and there is spiciness in nearly every dish even though it's not listed on the menu. The scallops on their own tasted good but in the taco not so much. They were sold out of the softshell crab and hamachi collar so come for lunch if you want to catch those.  May come back to try those.

I always bring people to la Paloma because if they're into seafood,  there are others restaurants to choose from.
This was the spot to get good ceviche! Now, it is a mission to get your order, the place is now so popular , expect to wait in line for about an hour.
They have added additional tables to accommodate the  demand

1. Seafood Tostada

A crispy tostada topped with plenty of fresh shrimp and fish! The sauce was a bit strong, but the ingredients were incredibly fresh. It felt like eating a piece of the ocean in one bite.

2. Tuna Tartare

The crispy minced tuna topped with avocado was visually and flavorfully satisfying. The tortillas provided a variety of textures, and the sauce was beautifully presented.

3. Green Shrimp Aguachile

The large shrimp and the green sauce were refreshing and tangy. The cucumber and onion complemented each other well, leaving a lasting impression. The flavor could be a bit strong.

4. Raw Oyster Plate

Fresh oysters generously served on ice! The basics were perfect, and the three different sauces made it even more enjoyable to enjoy. The refreshing flavor was a bonus.

5. Uni in Sea Urchin Shell

The visuals were absolutely stunning! However, the strong sauce underneath overshadowed the uni's unique savory flavor, which was a shame. The visual appeal was truly Instagram-worthy.

6. Octopus Grill Plate

The octopus was chewy on the outside and had a smoky flavor! The grilled lemon, avocado, and tomato salad complemented the dish perfectly, making both the plating and the taste satisfying.

7. Two Tacos (Fish + Octopus)

The fish taco had a crispy batter and the savory sauce complemented it well. The octopus taco was bursting with smoky flavor! Both were served on blue corn tortillas, adding a unique touch of color.

Picking peas were $8.

reviews.raw_text:
First time at Holbox, and boy! It was delightful. The prices are fair for the freshness of the food cooked and serviced here. I ended up getting the Uni and Pulpo de las Brasas.

The color of the uni was vibrant, fresh, buttery, and melted in your mouth. It is served with the sea urchin and has scallops inside.

The pulpo was cooked just right! It was not hard, nor chewy. Plenty of flavor, and the dish is served with pesto rice, black beans, avocado and cherry tomatoes mixed with purple onions and a grilled lemon on the side.

For drink, I went with the sparkling lemonade, and it was so refreshing!

I recommend this spot! Check them out!

reviews.raw_text:
They seated us at the restaurant which was nice, but we waited to get our order taken. Two couples who were behind us got their order taken at the register while we waited to get ours taken by a waiter. We got three different tacos and a shrimp cocktail. The tacos were great along with their hot sauces that they had on the side. The cocktail was good but half of the shrimps tasted like they had been freezer burned or had a weird chemical taste to it. I had my partner try it as well and they confirmed that some tasted like how they were supposed to taste and some tasted off. They took our plates that we finished so we could have more room which was nice. The cocktail was around $17-18 and the tacos were $7 each.

reviews.raw_text:
Holbox has earned its Michelin one-star recognition year after year, and honestly, it‚Äôs easy to see why. The flavors are bold, fresh, and layered ‚Äî and the prices are still super reasonable. Just be ready to wait a bit on weekends, especially during peak hours.
üî• Must-tries
Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta ‚Äì Not just stunning to look at (hello black taco shell), but packed with flavor. The octopus is tender, and while it leans salty, the squid ink base gives it a deep, savory vibe ‚Äî almost like olive tapenade.

üî• Ceviche Mixto ‚Äì Bright, zesty, and super refreshing. Octopus, shrimp, and sea bass come together with citrus in a way that‚Äôs perfect for anyone who loves sashimi or raw bar bites.

üî• Tostada de Kampachi + Uni ‚Äì
This is your treat yourself moment. Rich, luxe, and ridiculously good.
The casual counter setup at Mercado La Paloma adds to the charm ‚Äî it‚Äôs not fancy, but the food easily rivals upscale spots.

üí° Pro tip: Come early, grab a drink while you wait, and make it a mini food adventure.

Food: 5
Service: 4
Atmosphere: 4
Reservation: Walk-ins only
Noise level: Loud, but you can still talk
Wait time: 30-60 min
Parking space: Somewhat difficult to find parking
Parking options: Free parking lot

reviews.raw_text:
If you're looking for an unforgettable dining experience, Holbox is the place to be. From the moment we walked in, we were greeted with warm, friendly service and a cozy atmosphere that perfectly blends casual with chic. The ambiance set the tone for what would be an amazing meal.

Now, let's talk about the food ‚Äì wow! We tried a variety of tacos, and each one was better than the last. The fish taco was incredibly fresh, with a perfect balance of flavors. The shrimp taco was cooked to perfection, plump and juicy, with just the right amount of seasoning. But the real standout for me was the octopus taco ‚Äì tender and smoky, it had an incredible depth of flavor that really impressed us.

We also had the uni ‚Äì it was beyond amazing. Fresh, creamy, and melt-in-your-mouth delicious, it was a true treat for seafood lovers. Each bite was a reminder of just how high the quality of ingredients is at Holbox.

The tacos alone are worth a visit, but we also couldn‚Äôt resist the cocktails, which were perfectly crafted and paired so well with the meal. The staff was attentive but never overbearing, and we felt like they genuinely cared about our experience.

Overall, Holbox is one of those spots where you know you‚Äôre going to get high-quality food and service every time. I‚Äôll definitely be coming back to try more of their delicious dishes ‚Äì it‚Äôs worth every penny!

Price per person: $20‚Äì30
Food: 5
Service: 5
Atmosphere: 5
Noise level: Moderate noise
Wait time: 10-30 min

reviews.raw_text:
This is not a stand alone restaurant (although I wish it were), it‚Äôs inside of a food market. Seating is communal, so it will need to be shared with people dining at the other restaurants, that being said I‚Äôve never had a problem finding a table even for a large group, but that could very depending on which day of the week you‚Äôre dining out. I can‚Äôt speak too much on the service as they really only bring your food to you and bus your table after you‚Äôve finished. Now the reason why we‚Äôre really here is for the food, I would highly recommend the scallop ceviche. It is by far the best dish I have tried. The pulpo taco comes in second for me. Both of these dishes are a must. I‚Äôve tried a few other dishes, but nothing really worth noting, however I still have a list of things I‚Äôd like to try. The food tastes fresh every time, and the dishes are packed with flavor. I will be coming back.

reviews.raw_text:
A Michelin rated counter restaurant serving fresh, fresh seafood. In a Mexican food court close to USC and a mere few blocks from the USC/Jefferson Metro stop. Wait in line to order your dishes (grab a menu and be decisive), take a number and find a table.  If seats are open at the counter, grab them. We arrived at 2:30 and no counter seats but by the time we were finished several had opened up.  So if you want to sit at the counter, wait to order until you get a seat.  You still have to order!  Tried the sea urchin with scallops, octopus taco, ceviche mixto, and branzino filet.  All delicious.  There is a parking lot adjacent if you drive.  I think it's free.

3.5/5. I‚Äôm a bit spilt on Holbox. Many rave about it as it has a Michelin recognition. The food is very fresh as it‚Äôs constantly rotating due to the high demand. The menu is somewhat unique and there‚Äôs definitely interesting, palatable flavors and ingredients. However, it wasn‚Äôt overly delicious or unique enough to scream home about. You could have similar Mexican seafood experience in other mom and Pop restaurants around town. Personally, it wasn‚Äôt worth the hype.

There‚Äôs an attempt to have fast service, but you won‚Äôt be able to avoid the hour long wait. Longer, including getting your food. The place is located inside a packed and busy food hall, so it can be a struggle to find your own table. Another big thing is sanitation. Due to the high demand, there wasn‚Äôt a meticulous practice on keeping the stations, food prep, and cross contamination clean.

Amazing Food & Top-Notch Service!üëè

Holbox is hands down one of the best seafood spots in LA. We tried the ceviche mixto, taco de pulpo, smoked kanpachi taco, and the tostada de kanpachi with uni ‚Äî everything was incredibly fresh and bursting with flavor.

Even with a line, the wait wasn‚Äôt bad, and the staff went above and beyond. A team member kindly made sure we got seats at the bar without us even asking again ‚Äî it felt like they were really looking out for us. The chefs were friendly, knowledgeable, and proud of their craft. They took time to explain dishes and even let me sample the aguachile sauce based on my spice preference.

The ambiance is casual, market-style, but the energy and passion from the staff make it feel special. Watching someone deliver fresh fish straight into the kitchen was the cherry on top. Big thanks to the entire Holbox team ‚Äî you made our visit unforgettable!

reviews.raw_text:
I'm OBSESSED. I love this place, I work so close and I can't believe I never knew about this place in the last 5 years. Everything I've tried here is amazing. My favorites might be the smoked kanpachi taco, taco de pulpo en su tinta, scallop taco, and the churros are the best churros I've ever had (which I kind of feel bad for saying bc I've tried churros in Spain). I'm gonna try their entire menu over time, and I'm sure I'm gonna love every single menu item.

Besides the amazing food, the service is also really great!!! In addition, they list all the allergens in their food on the menu, so I was able to take my friend who is gluten-free there without any worries!!

I've brought so many people here since I found out about it 2 weeks ago.

Most of the time the line might get long, but they move fairly quickly.

In a food court renovated from an industrial plant near USC, this is one of dozens of food stalls and the most popular one. It was awarded a Michelin star in 2024 and won the Plate Award or Bib Gourmand in previous years. I just came back from South America, so I skipped ceviche, the national dish of South America and Mexico. In addition to the must-order scallops and sea urchins for every table, I strongly recommend "Scallop Aguachile", which is scallop chili soup with avocado. A dozen delicious scallops surround the avocado cut into a flower shape, and it is very delicious when soaked in chili sauce. Next time I should try octopus tacos.

reviews.raw_text:
I had the great pleasure of dining at Holbox, a culinary gem nestled within the vibrant La Paloma market near USC, just south of Downtown Los Angeles. This remarkable restaurant, helmed by the talented and deeply passionate Chef Gilbert Cetina, more than earns its Michelin star distinction.

Seated at the counter, diners are treated not only to an extraordinary meal, but to the mesmerizing theater of preparation, with Chef Cetina personally engaging guests as he crafts each dish with precision and care.

For an unforgettable experience, I recommend visiting on a Wednesday or Thursday evening, when the eight-course tasting menu is available. Each course is a revelation ‚Äî inventive, impeccably balanced, and a true celebration of Mexico‚Äôs coastal cuisine.

Holbox is, without exaggeration, one of the finest restaurants in Los Angeles, and without question the best Mexican seafood restaurant I‚Äôve ever had the joy of experiencing. The variety of fish is unmatched, with a menu grounded in locally sourced, line-caught seafood, honoring both sustainability and flavor in every bite.

Atmosphere: 5

reviews.raw_text:
Undoubtedly the best seafood in Los Angeles and finally getting their much deserved Michelin star in 2024. I have been wanting to visit Holbox for over two years but never had the chance until now.

It‚Äôs all about fresh seafood with a very latin flavor. Several kinds of ceviches, tacos, and tostadas gave the menu away.  That sweet and citrusy scallop aquachile made me wanted to drink the rest of the juice , and how about an octopus taco (blew my mind away) we just got back from Lisbon and this was equally great.  As food were prepared we just kept saying ‚Äúwow‚Äù as they pass us by we‚Äôll have that next time.  If only we had bigger stomachs but there is always a next time.  And those churros for dessert was so good it brought us back to our favorite churros in Seville.  Located inside a food hall surrounded by equally great latin faire reminds me of a small hawker center in Singapore minus the satay grills. Chef Celina definitely upped the ante and has been consistent in his quality since 2017.

We came early and first in line which was awesome because as soon as they opened, the line was already snaking around the parking lot. That only tells you great food with no frills, served well is what makes a perfect meal.

I'm still thinking about the pulpo I had there! This place had some very very fresh ceviche. Highly recommend. We weren't expecting to sit at the bar, but they had some seating open (it's very limited). Great service. The home made lemonade is perfectly refreshing. For being Michelin starred, I think one comment is that the two ceviches we got had the same type of flavor. I couldn't really tell the flavors apart between fishes because it was covered by the same ceviche flavor profile. It was delicious nonetheless, but I wonder if other fish dishes on the menu are the same...as I said, I still think about the pulpo. Perfect char, accompanied by the perfect sauce.

Ok, I didn't expect too much from a restaurant with a walk-up counter, and after spending a half-hour waiting in line, my first visit, I was curious what the buzz in the air was. We found a seat in the food court, and a short time later my grilled octopus dinner plate, my wife's three tacos, and the sea urchin and scallop ceviche arrived. Looks impressive, but would it hit the mark?
YES!!! I must say the food far surpassed any expectations I may have had!!!  So much so, I took the 30-mile trip from home again last weekend to try some more Holbox food. This time, I enjoyed the mixed seafood cocktail and three tacos (Baja, aged hamachi, and octopus). My wife went for the grilled octopus plate.
In one word, YUM!!!
It will not be long before we return again!
I rank the food as a 5, the service as a 4 (only because I prefer sit-down and waiter service,  and atmosphere a 3 because I think this food deserves a classier spot, but for the quality of the fare, you can't beat the price!
BRAVO HOLBOX!!!

reviews.raw_text:
Arguably one of the best restaurants I‚Äôve ever been to. Michelin starred for five years and rightfully so. There‚Äôs no glitz and glam just straightforward amazing food. It‚Äôs located in a food hall/market so you order at the counter and they bring the food to you, but there are a few counter seats available as well.
Everything was super fresh, which you can tell by the fresh fish that are on display in the cooler right behind the chefs. The staff is very helpful and attentive. We spoke with one of the owners Briana and you can tell she has a true passion for what she does.
We went here three nights in a row, not for lack of restaurant options as there are plenty to choose from in Los Angeles, but because it was just an amazing experience all around.
We tried the scallop Agua Chile, several of the tostadas, all the tacos, the grilled kanpachi collars, coctel de camarones, the scallop and Uni ceviche, and several other dishes. Every single, one of them deserves perfect reviews. Their freshly made blue corn tortillas alone are worth the trip.
Prices are very modest and won‚Äôt break the bank for the quality of food and service that you receive. Add this to your must try list for the next time you‚Äôre in LA.

reviews.raw_text:
We couldn‚Äôt be happier with the food vendor we chose for our wedding‚Äîit was phenomenal! Even six months later, we still have guests raving about how delicious and memorable the food was. The flavors were bold, authentic, and elevated‚Äîeverything you‚Äôd want from high-quality Mexican cuisine, especially for a wedding. The presentation was beautiful, and the entire meal felt both festive and refined.

Despite some challenges with our venue not allowing them to use the indoor kitchen, the team worked seamlessly with an outdoor kitchen setup we arranged. They handled the situation with complete professionalism, flexibility, and a great attitude. The food was hot, fresh, and incredibly flavorful. From start to finish, everything was clean, well-organized, and sanitary.

One of the highlights was the late-night tacos‚Äîguests loved them! My husband mentioned how much he enjoyed their salsa, and they generously offered him the entire bottle to take home at the end of the night, which was such a thoughtful touch. The desserts were equally incredible‚Äîespecially the churros, which were made fresh on the spot and absolutely unforgettable.

There was more than enough food for everyone, and we were even given leftovers to take home. They also handled all the cleanup and removed every bit of trash from the site. Their team was so professional, both in how they dressed and how they interacted with our guests. Even some of our pickiest guests commented on how much they enjoyed the food‚Äîwhich says a lot!

We highly, highly recommend this vendor for any event. They helped make our wedding not just delicious, but unforgettable.

Food: 5
Service: 5
Atmosphere: 5

reviews.raw_text:
Hidden Gem That Earned Its Star ‚Äì Holbox, Los Angeles

IG: the_hungry_emil

I've been dining at¬†Holbox¬†inside Paloma Market for years, well before it earned its Michelin star, and it's been consistently exceptional every single time.

This visit began with the¬†Halibut Tostada, showcasing incredibly fresh fish over a smooth avocado pur√©e with vibrant pico de gallo‚Äîlight, crisp, and full of flavor.

Next up, the¬†Scallop Aguachile¬†truly impressed. Raw scallops were sweet and briny, perfectly balanced by a zesty green chile-lime sauce, and beautifully presented with red onions and an avocado rose.

I then sampled a trio of tacos:

The¬†Octopus Taco¬†was unlike any I‚Äôve had‚Äîtender grilled octopus served on a deep, savory squid ink sofrito with bright bursts of tomato and chive.

The¬†Scallop Taco¬†featured a seared scallop, lightly caramelized on the outside, paired with a peppery sauce and shredded lettuce for freshness.

The¬†Smoked Kampachi Taco¬†came in a crisp shell, delivering a subtle smokiness to the cooked yellowtail‚Äîunique and absolutely delicious.

Every dish reflects a careful blend of traditional Baja flavors with modern technique and elegance. Holbox is a must-visit for anyone who loves Mexican seafood done right‚Äîand elevated to fine-dining standards.

Service: 5
Atmosphere: 5

Everything here is simply fantastic.

I stopped by Tuesday around noon (of course, right at lunch time) and parking was horrendous but I'm sure it's this bad any time of the day considering how small the lot is and how little street parking is available.

The line was long but moved at a good pace. The cashier was super sweet and offered good recommendations while also explaining the meaning of Holbox when I asked so thank you to her!

I ordered a little bit of everything to get the full range of taste.

First up was the ceviche de atuna or tuna ceviche. Wow. Some of the freshest most amazing tuna you'll find, this beats out a lot of sushi restaurants too. The ceviche had great flavor and the chips/tostadas on the side were the perfect pairing. My only minor complaint here was the somewhat off-balance of ceviche mix to tuna. The mix is a bit overpowering and I started picking out more of the tuna, because there was already so much stuck onto each piece.

Next up was the kanpachi tostada. My fault for not eating this right away as the tostada got a bit soggy but wow - another stellar dish. The uni was the cherry on top to add a textural change as well as that ocean freshness.

The baja fish taco has to be one of the best fish tacos, even one of the best tacos I've ever had in LA. Simply done even at Michelin standards. The fish was light and so crispy, the tortilla was soft and fresh, and the salsa was perfect.

Lastly and another amazing dish - the smoked kanpachi quesadilla. The Kanpachi was sooo good and light, it was cheesy and the salsa added so much depth of flavor.

This place is a must for any Mexican and seafood lover

Holbox might just be the best food court or fast-casual dining experience you‚Äôll ever have. The quality coming out of this kitchen far exceeds what you‚Äôd expect from a counter-service setup‚Äîit‚Äôs almost a mismatch in the best possible way.

Ordering was smooth and easy, and the food arrived quickly. Chips and salsa were served first, which was a nice touch while we waited for the main dishes.

The setting can be seen as either charming or simply casual, but either way, there‚Äôs ample seating in the food court, so finding a table isn‚Äôt an issue.

While I personally find this style of casual dining a bit unglamorous‚Äîand wish I could enjoy a cold beer with my ceviche‚ÄîI recognize that the stripped-down setup keeps overhead low, and that value is clearly passed on to the customer.

I also had the limonada, which was crisp and refreshing. Every dish felt thoughtful and vibrant. I left so satisfied and already can‚Äôt wait to come back to try more. An absolute must for seafood lovers in LA!

reviews.raw_text:
Holbox ‚Äì A Missed Catch in a City Full of Great Tacos

I really wanted to love Holbox. It‚Äôs one of LA‚Äôs most talked-about spots‚ÄîMichelin-starred, James Beard‚Äìnominated, raved about on every food blog worth its salt. But for us, it just didn‚Äôt land.

From the start, service was disorganized. Our dessert arrived before our food, and we had to flag down three different team members just to get our order. They did refund the dessert‚Äîwhich we appreciated‚Äîbut honestly, it wasn‚Äôt worth serving in the first place. The cheesecake was dense, dry, and flavorless. It felt like an afterthought in a place that shouldn‚Äôt be mailing anything in.

The lobster dish was a real letdown. Coming from a coastal town where lobster is a way of life, I was excited‚Äîbut what arrived was chewy and overcooked. The rice and beans alongside it were actually great, but not what you come here for.

Michael ordered an assortment of tacos. The scallop taco was undercooked and had an off taste. The smoked kampachi taco had a cool concept, but wasn‚Äôt something either of us wanted more than a bite of. The Baja shrimp taco? That one was solid‚Äîbut LA is a city of incredible tacos. If you‚Äôre going to be one of the top taco spots here, you really have to bring it. Holbox didn‚Äôt.

The ceviche was the one bright spot in terms of taste. The fish was fresh and well-marinated, but it was plated in a way that felt messy and overwhelming. The portion was huge and oddly presented‚Äîmore cafeteria scoop than culinary elegance.

The fryer oil was another surprise. I have a soybean allergy‚Äîto boot‚Äîso I couldn‚Äôt even try some of the items, including the chips and fish tacos I was most excited about. They use a blended oil with soybean in their fryer, which was really unfortunate.

There‚Äôs a lot of potential here‚Äîfresh fish, inventive ideas, a casual setup that‚Äôs very LA. But execution matters, and for us, it just didn‚Äôt deliver.

In the end, the best things I had were my Diet Coke, the rice and beans, and a taco I couldn‚Äôt even eat. It‚Äôs safe to say we won‚Äôt be returning. If we ever do find ourselves back at this market, we‚Äôll be trying the other counters instead.

Had an amazing time here, truly the best bang for your buck for fresh, authentic Mexican seafood in LA that is, yes, Michelin starred! In additional to sampling a few tacos and tostadas (I prefer the tacos in terms of the vehicle for the seafood - the tortilla is really soft and supple), we also splurged on the uni, which came freshly cracked open and loaded with scallop. What also shocked me was how good the DESSERT was - one of the best churros I've ever had, pillowy and the chocolate sauce was just the right consistency and sweetness. Service was great and there was plenty of seating in the food hall. Overall, an excellent meal!

the tacos next time and let you know.

reviews.raw_text:
We've been loyal and frequent customers since the early days and it's been a fantastic experience.
As with everything else, change is never fun especially if that means no more complimentary chips and salsa, now charged IF you want to opt-in for just over a $1 for a single portion.
We spent over $100 (this included a couple of Hot sauces to-go at 6.95 each >> well worth it) you would think that they would re-consider the chips and salsa based on customer spending.

Lines definitely gotten LONGER and can take well over 30-minutes before you can place your order (still worth it though).
The food does seem different, just can't tell if that Qty has been adjusted but again, taste has not changed at all and is still top notch.
Paid parking makes sense, DMV parking lot in the back is still free and available after 5pm and weekends.
I have not yet decided if I will reduce the frequency of visits or continue to try until they perhaps start charging for the hot sauces and seating.

I finally tried this place on my day off! There was a line that moved pretty fast at 1:30pm, but it was slow by 3pm. Plenty of food court seating. I found street parking easily on a weekday. The seafood was definitely fresh and yummy. I tried their octopus taco, smoked kanpachi taco, uni/kanpachi tostada, and shrimp aguachile. My fav was probably the tostada, but I have to say the uni was lost in the strong flavors of the ceviche. I'd say try any of the ceviche options to be satisfied.

Their operation is clearly well run, affordable for what the menu is, and presentation is amazing. But I was expecting more from the flavors. I didn't find any of the flavors innovative or new. Their tacos are simple and that's an item that can easily be experimented on. They have a good sized menu. I wish it was smaller and even more simple to showcase the fresh seafood or have more experimental/innovative options on the menu. Overall it was a good seafood experience. I'm not sure how I'd feel if I had to battle a weekend line. Also, not sure if I'd go out of my way to come back on my own, but for sure with newcomers. I'd love to try their other ceviche options.

reviews.raw_text:
Came here on a Sunday and joined the line around 11:15, before they opened and the line was already out the door. Ordered by 11:50 and got my food by noon. If you're going to come here, aim for off-peak hours or come early. Got the Ceviche Mixto, Kanpachi and Uni Tostada, and Baja Fish Taco. Everything was perfect. Their octopus and scallop are exceptional. Everything else was honestly on par with other good, non-Michelin taco spots.

I will say, only the line is a long wait. After your order, they actually bring your food out pretty quickly, and they'll bring it out as it's ready. Plenty of seating inside and outside, you don't need to be one of those people who save a table before you've even ordered.

I will say, only the line is a long wait. After your order, they actually bring your food out pretty quickly, and they'll bring it out as it's ready. Plenty of seating inside and outside, you don't need to be one of those people who save a table before you've even ordered.

reviews.raw_text:
One of the more amazing Mexican/seafood food experiences I‚Äôve had! The fish was sooo fresh. Flavors, excellent. Portions were also substantial.

Highlight: kanpachi ceviche (portion was huge and tostadas nice and crispy) and the tuna tostada

Only thing that lacked a little was the octopus taco. The flavors were great, but the octopus was a little dry and not very large pieces.

Be prepared for a line. We waited around 30ish minutes at 2:00 on a Sunday. However, it is well worth the wait!

reviews.raw_text:
I had very high expectations for Holbox but I left quite disappointed. The Branzino seabass was mediocre at best, it lacked flavor and texture. The taco de pescado al carbon was a bit dry and the Baja shrimp taco was sadly overcooked and bland. Shrimp cannot be overcooked on any dish at a Michelin star hyped restaurant. We also tried the kanpachi uni tostada which was pretty good and worth a try but not the most memorable tostada I‚Äôve ever had. The atmosphere was typical of a Mercado which is fine but the food did not impress or warrant the time invested in its wait.

reviews.raw_text:
Extremely disappointed in the Holbox experience. The food was decent at best with no one dish truly standing out. I had the c√≥ctel mixto, the pecado a las brasas (sea bass), tostada de Kanpachi & Uni, taco de pescado al carb√≥n, baja shrimp taco, and a lemonade.

The standout dish among those was the kanpachi & uni tostada but that not saying much considering all the dishes were of average quality. I expected more from the hype and was disappointed.  As I looked around the Mercado I realized that people had exceptional dishes from the other restaurants in the market. The atmosphere was typical of a Mercado, busy and loud, which is fine. However, the food left a lot to be desired given the Michelin acclaim and hype. I honestly believe the star isn‚Äôt justified and it was likely awarded because of where the restaurant is located (South L.A) and let‚Äôs face it, someone in the hood had to get a star.

went around 7:30pm on a saturday and the line out the door looked extremely long, but it was only like 30 minutes at most - and the food was SO worth the wait. everything looked beautiful, and tasted so fresh and delicious

we tried:
‚Ä¢ live urchin & scallop ceviche
‚Ä¢ smoked kanpachi tostada
‚Ä¢ smoked kanpachi taco
‚Ä¢ taco de pulpo
‚Ä¢ baja fish taco
‚Ä¢ kanpachi & uni tostada

i enjoyed everything, but my favorites were definitely the live urchin & scallop ceviche and smoked kanpachi tostada. the live urchin & scallop ceviche was SO tasty - its bright & acidic flavors reminded me a lot of peruvian ceviche. it was a pretty pricey dish but it was very seafood-forward - definitely a must-order if you‚Äôre only looking to try a couple things. i loved the texture of the scallops in the smoked kanpachi tostada - they were very tender and fresh-tasting. i will definitely be missing the fresh seafood here until the next time i‚Äôm in the area

This is the first Michelin star restaurant I have ever been to, and it did not disappoint one bit. It is inside of a food court, and the line gets insanely long, but it is well worth the wait. I came on Saturday for lunch and waited around an hour in line. The food was insanely good, beautifully presented and big portions that are actually very good value for the price. Every single item was extremely fresh and delicious. Once you get a number you can find a table either inside or outside and the staff will find you and bring your food. Absolutely recommended, top tier on all metrics.

reviews.plain_text: This is the first Michelin star restaurant I have ever been to, and it did not disappoint one bit. It is inside of a food court, and the line gets insanely long, but it is well worth the wait. I came on Saturday for lunch and waited around an hour in line. The food was insanely good, beautifully presented and big portions that are actually very good value for the price. Every single item was extremely fresh and delicious. Once you get a number you can find a table either inside or outside and the staff will find you and bring your food. Absolutely recommended, top tier on all metrics.

reviews.raw_text:
holbox is a stall in a food hall in downtown Los Angeles so there is a queue to order food and they give you a number for self-seating. I arrived at 12pm on a Friday and waited in line for about an hour before ordering my food. I probably would not go there again as I wasn't that wowed with the flavors and dishes (though I know they do offer tasting menu reservations only on Wednesdays and Thursdays which I haven't tried) but the appeal really is that they are accessible and a low cost ($ one dollar sign) Michelin in LA.

+ Octopus is well cooked
+ Raw scallop dishes yummy
+ Price!!!
+ Seafood tastes fresh

- Avoid lunch and dinner rush hours, not necessarily worth the wait
- parking in DTLA is a nightmare

Went here on a Friday afternoon at opening. There was already a line to get in. However, you can also sit at the counter and get table service there. I found an empty seat and took advantage. It's located in a food court, so expect a packed house.

I was helped quickly by a gentleman. I started off with a sparkling lemonade and a taco de pulpo en su tinta. The taco was very good. The octopus was tender and went well with the calamari ink sofrito. Next I got a tostada de atun. Bluefin tuna, avocado puree and arbol peanut sauce. The combination of all 3 were great! And the homemade tostada was easy to eat. Didn't crumble at any bites, so you're enjoying every component of the plate. Lastly, I got an entr√©e of pulpo a la brasa. The smokiness of the octopus combined with the almond pipian was spot-on! Combine that to make a taco with the baby tomatoes and avocado slices it was a perfect combo!

Overall, a great experience at $57.00. The server was attentive, although his attitude changed after my 15% tip. It's all good. Doesn't take away from the overall experience. I highly recommend coming here.

reviews.raw_text:
Wife and I went for early dinner around 3:30 on Sunday (1/19/25). Got a parking spot right away. There was already a 20 deep line just for Holbox. Ordered around 4 pm the grilled octopus plate (pulpo a las brasas), grilled kanpachi collars and a cold halibut tostada (tostada de lenguado). Attentive servers delivered chips and salsa right away. Food started arriving in 20 minutes. Halibut tostada was awesome and fresh. Octopus plate with habanero sauce was just the best...no rubbery morsel here!!! My wife thoroughly enjoyed the fish collar. In between, the wait staff were quick to add a baja fish taco my wife wanted to try. I would go back just to have the same dishes let alone try other items on the menu!! Gave ambiance only 4 stars because Holbox wasn't the only restaurant in the mercado plaza...but it was the primary attraction. BTW, when we left around 5:30 the line was even longer!!

reviews.raw_text:
Came to this place while in town yesterday and have been wanting to try this since watching an episode of a food show on Youtube they were featured on. This honestly has to be top 5-10 best meals I've ever had in my life. Seriously. The seafood is so fresh and melts in your mouth. I had the garlic butter shrimp plate with the grilled bread, cilantro rice, and beans, and the flavor of the shrimp sauce was AMAZING. Since I was hungry, I had an array of different items, including the Tostada with the Kampachi, shrimp, and another fish, and it was out of this world!! The salsas are soooo good! The guacamole was cool (maybe needed a pinch of salt). But the showstopper were the CHURROS. Oh my god!!! Those Churros with the chocolate sauce? INSANE!!! Honestly, I'm going back again before I leave but seriously, this place is beyond words. The prices are reasonable but also range, depending on the dish and it's worth every penny. This place is deserving of its Michellin star and more. Thank you for creating this magical place. Holbox, I love you!!!

Service: 5
Atmosphere: 5

reviews.raw_text:
What can one say about Holbox? It is in a big food court. It has gotten a lot of press, and has a Michelin star. I will start with the food, but I have a lot to say about the experience.

You can upload the menu on your phone or get someone in your group to grab a menu. It is good to use your wait time in the long line to the ordering counter wisely. Send others to grab drinks from another vendor. Buy a few tacos from another vendor if you are hungry.

We tried a lot of dishes. The Baja shrimp taco is traditional, but the shrimp are huge and moist, and the crema and toppings are great. Also quite good was the tostado de jurel. It is yellowtail ceviche, avocado, and an almond salsa on a very crispy corn tortilla base. It was fresh, sour, savory, and yummy. I found the scallop aguachile to be a bit too lime forward, which tends to drown out the sweetness of scallops, but if you eat it with the pieces of avocado and chips, it mellows everything out. Needless to say, all the seafood is bright and fresh.

My companions really loved the smoked kanpachi tacos, all hot and cheesy, and spicy. The camarones al mojo were sensational. This is a main dish platter, so comes with excellent black beans and cilantro rice, plus toasted bread for sopping up the marinade. The shrimp were HUGE and perfectly prepared. So all in all, the food is terrific.

So the downsides: You will pretty much have a 30 to 45 minute wait before you can order. You will need to hunt out a table in the loud, noisy, and not very clean dining hall. The food comes out in no particular order. This makes the actual dining rather chaotic. Our 6 items cost over $100. Michelin star or not, to me, how I am served and the atmosphere in which I eat makes a difference. Is the food great? Yes. Does eating it amid the chaos make it less nice? Yes, absolutely.

I have eaten at a lot of Michelin started restaurants all over the world. Does this rate a Michelin star? I don't think so. But I do recommend eating here. The food is just terrific.
